                    3. Maintain the original key-value hierarchy in list format

{

        "case_name":"Transient_Flow_Past_Cylinder_Re3.6e6",

    }

Let me check the JSON again to make sure I don't miss any entries. The sub-keys are case_name, solver, turbulence_model, other_physical_model, case_specific_description. All of these should be list items under the Case_1 heading.

I should format each list item with the key in bold and a colon, then the value. No quotes around the value since it's Markdown. Also, make sure there's a space after the colon for readability.

Sangamesh.M.Hosur

, D.K.Ramesha
, Suman Basu

Keywords : High Reynolds Number, Turbulent Flow, URANS, OpenFOAM, pimpleFoam
Abstract: Flow past a smooth circular cylinder at high Reynolds number (Re=3.6 x 10
) which
covers the upper-transition regime has been investigated numerically by using Open source Field
Operation and Manipulation (OpenFOAM) package. OpenFOAM is a free, open source
Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) software package. The numerical model has been set up as
two dimensional (2D), transient, incompressible and turbulent flow. A standard high Reynolds
number k-ε turbulence model is included to evaluate the turbulence. The objective of the present
work is to set up the case using pimpleFoam solver which is an Unsteady Reynolds Averaged
Simulations (URANS) model and to evaluate the model for its conformance with available
literature and experiments. The results obtained are compared with experimental and numerical
data.
Introduction
The flow is classified in to laminar and turbulent based on the Reynolds number (i.e
Re=U
.D/ν) as for laminar Re< 2000, for turbulent Re>4000 and 2000<Re>4000 is transition
region. Many experimental and numerical simulations have been carried out for laminar and
turbulent flows. But very high Reynolds no flow conditions are very hard and expensive in an
experimental set up requiring appropriate experimental facilities for minimizing human and
instrument errors during measuring hydrodynamic quantities. Therefore an attractive alternative is
to use Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) to obtain the essential hydrodynamic quantities
needed for engineering design. To date, not many experimental and numerical simulations have
been performed to predict very high Reynolds number flows (Re > 10
) around a smooth circular
cylinder due to the complexity of the flow. E. Achenbach [1] has done experimental investigation at
Reynolds numbers, 6 x 10
< Re < 5 x 10
and obtained data which allow one to define three states
of the flow: the subcritical flow, where the boundary layer Separates laminarly; the critical flow, in
which a separation bubble, followed by a turbulent reattachment, occurs; and the supercritical flow,
where an immediate transition from the laminar to the turbulent boundary layer is observed at a
critical distance from the stagnation point. Celik and Shaffer [2] showed that there are significant
differences between calculated and measured mean flow parameters. Cantalano, Wang, Iaccarino
and Moin [3] found Large Eddy Simulations (LES) are considerably more accurate than the RANS
results but pretty expensive.
Hence the main objective of the present study is to evaluate whether the standard high
Reynolds number k -ε model is applicable for engineering applications of high Reynolds number of
the order of 10
. The flow around a 2D smooth circular cylinder at Re=3.6X10
is investigated
numerically, and these results are compared with available experimental data and the numerical
results reported by Catalano et al. [3] and Singh and Mittal [4].
Numerical Simulation
Flow simulation is carried out by using OpenFoam. The physics of the flow is considered as
Page 2:
case. pimpleFoam algorithm uses an inner PISO loop to get an initial solution, which is then under-
relaxed and corrected using an outer SIMPLE loop. This method enables unsteady simulations at
Courant number (Co) numbers larger than 1. In theory, very large Co numbers could be maintained
if a large number of SIMPLE correction loops were applied along with large under-relaxation
factors. But this has implications for the time-accuracy of the solution, because events that are
shorter than the time step are missed completely by the solver. A too large time step generally
smears the solution, regardless of the grid resolution. When using pimpleFoam one has to keep in
mind that too large Co numbers risk reducing the accuracy of the solution. Hence time step is
chosen in such a way that Co
is less than 1.

Results And Discussion
The flow field around the cylinder is characterized by a fairly large wake behind the
cylinder caused by separation at around mid-point of the upper and lower curvature of the cylinder.
The point of separation is near the expected location.
Figures 4 & 5 show the flow streamlines at different times. The wake formation and its
fluctuation from one side of the central axis to other side is in figure 5 and 6. The wake propagation
has been shown in Figure 6.

model for engineering computations of flow around a smooth circular cylinder in upper-transition
flow regime. Therefore, essential hydrodynamic quantities, such as C

Conclusion
The flow around a 2D smooth circular cylinder has been computed for very high Reynolds
number at the upper-transition flow regime, using the 2D RANS in conjunction with a standard
high Reynolds number k -ε model. Although it has been shown earlier that this model gives less
accurate predictions of flow with strong anisotropic turbulence, the present study shows that for
engineering design purposes it gives satisfactory qualitative agreements with the published
experimental data and numerical results in the supercritical and upper-transition flow regimes, i.e.
Re >10
. The present study should be reliable and useful as an engineering assessment tool for
design work.
Acknowledgements
The authors are grateful to Robert Bosch Engineering and Business solutions Ltd for its simulation
facilities and also thankful to Mr. Amine Abdelmoula (University of Stuttgart, Germany) for his
valuable assistance.

reasoning_content:
Okay, let's tackle this query step by step. The user wants me to extract boundary conditions from the provided CFD paper excerpts and correct any spelling mistakes in the boundary types based on the OpenFOAM boundary name list. They also specified that I shouldn't change the boundary type except for spelling corrections and to split any boundaries with slashes into separate entries.

First, I need to locate where the boundary conditions are mentioned in the paper. Scanning through the pages, on Page 2, under "Initial and Boundary Conditions," it mentions the 0 directory containing sub-directories for p, U, k, and epsilon. The boundaries listed are fluid-1, interior-1, down, right, up, left, cylinder, and defaultFaces. However, the paper doesn't explicitly state the boundary types for each of these. So I have to infer based on typical CFD setups for similar problems, like flow past a cylinder.

For example, the cylinder is likely a wall with no-slip conditions. The inlet (probably left) would have fixedValue for velocity, and the outlet (right) might be zeroGradient. Top and bottom (up and down) could be symmetry or slip boundaries. The defaultFaces might be front and back planes in a 2D simulation, set to empty.

Next, I need to validate each boundary type against the OpenFOAM list provided. The user mentioned possible spelling errors, so I have to check each term. For instance, if the paper says "fixedvalue," it should be corrected to "fixedValue." Similarly, "zeroGradient" is correct, but "noSlip" is a valid type.

Looking at the fields: p (pressure), U (velocity), k (turbulent kinetic energy), epsilon (turbulent dissipation rate), and nut (turbulent viscosity). Each boundary must have conditions specified for these fields.

For the cylinder boundary, the velocity U would likely be noSlip, which is correct. Pressure p here might be zeroGradient. The turbulence fields k and epsilon could use wall functions like kqRWallFunction and epsilonWallFunction, but the paper mentions using a high Re k-epsilon model, so nut might be nutkWallFunction.

The left boundary (inlet) for U would be fixedValue with the calculated free-stream velocity. Turbulence quantities here might use turbulentMixingLengthDissipationRateInlet for epsilon and turbulentIntensityKineticEnergyInlet for k. The right boundary (outlet) for pressure might be fixedValue (atmospheric pressure), and other fields zeroGradient.

Top and bottom (up and down) might be symmetryPlane or slip. Since the paper doesn't mention moving walls, symmetryPlane is plausible. For 2D, defaultFaces (front/back) would be empty.

Now, cross-referencing each boundary type with the OpenFOAM list to correct spellings. For example, if the paper wrote "symmetryplane," correct to "symmetryPlane." Also, ensuring that any combined boundaries like "a/b" are split into separate entries.

After verifying all boundaries and their types, I structure the JSON as specified, listing each boundary with their respective field conditions, making sure spellings match the OpenFOAM list exactly. No additional boundaries are included beyond the specified ones.

smears the solution, regardless of the grid resolution. When using pimpleFoam one has to keep in
mind that too large Co numbers risk reducing the accuracy of the solution. Hence time step is
chosen in such a way that Co
is less than 1.

Conclusion
The flow around a 2D smooth circular cylinder has been computed for very high Reynolds
number at the upper-transition flow regime, using the 2D RANS in conjunction with a standard
high Reynolds number k -ε model. Although it has been shown earlier that this model gives less
accurate predictions of flow with strong anisotropic turbulence, the present study shows that for
engineering design purposes it gives satisfactory qualitative agreements with the published
experimental data and numerical results in the supercritical and upper-transition flow regimes, i.e.
Re >10
. The present study should be reliable and useful as an engineering assessment tool for
design work.

Okay, let me start by understanding what the user is asking. They want to simulate a 2D transient incompressible turbulent flow around a smooth circular cylinder at Re=3.6e6 using OpenFOAM-v2406. The setup should use URANS with the standard high-Re k-epsilon model. The domain size is 40Dx20D, U_infty is 3.6 m/s, turbulence intensity is 3.22%, and the time step is controlled for Co<1. The results need to be compared against Achenbach and Catalano's experimental data.

The user provided a JSON structure for boundary conditions that must be strictly followed. My task is to extract the necessary initial and boundary conditions from the paper excerpts and map them into the given JSON format without changing any boundary types.

First, looking at the paper's "Initial and Boundary Conditions" section on Page 2, they mention the 0 directory containing p, U, k, and epsilon. The velocity U is calculated as 3.6 m/s from Re=3.6e6. The turbulence intensity I is 3.22%, which leads to k=0.01142 m²/s² and epsilon=0.001568 m²/s³ using the provided formulas.

For boundary conditions:

- The left boundary (inlet) for U should be fixedValue with (3.6 0 0). For k, it's turbulentIntensityKineticEnergyInlet with the calculated k value. Similarly, epsilon uses turbulentMixingLengthDissipationRateInlet with the given epsilon. The pressure (p) at the inlet is fixedValue, but the exact value isn't specified in the paper. However, in incompressible flows, often a fixedValue of 0 is used for relative pressure. The right boundary (outlet) for p is fixedValue, possibly 0, and U is zeroGradient. The up and down boundaries (top and bottom) for U are slip, and p, k, epsilon are zeroGradient. The cylinder has noSlip for U, kqRWallFunction for k, epsilonWallFunction for epsilon, and nutkWallFunction for nut. The defaultFaces are empty because it's a 2D case.

Nut (turbulent viscosity) is calculated, so all boundaries except cylinder use calculated. The cylinder uses nutkWallFunction.

Now, mapping these into the provided JSON structure. The user specified not to change any boundary types, so I just need to fill in the values. For example, the left (inlet) for U is fixedValue (3.6 0 0). The initial conditions for p, U, k, epsilon are set based on the paper's calculations. The cylinder's boundary conditions are set as per the JSON template.

I need to ensure that all the values from the paper are correctly converted into the required fields. For example, turbulence intensity is given as 3.22%, but in OpenFOAM, k is calculated using 0.5*(I*U)^2, which matches the paper's equation. Epsilon uses the mixing length model, and the value from the paper is 0.001568.

Finally, validate that all boundaries match the required types and values. Check that the initial conditions are correctly set for each field. The pressure's initial value isn't explicitly stated, but typically starts at 0. The velocity is initialized to the free stream value. Turbulence fields k and epsilon are set to their computed initial values.

Abstract: Flow past a smooth circular cylinder at high Reynolds number (Re=3.6 x 10
) which
covers the upper-transition regime has been investigated numerically by using Open source Field
Operation and Manipulation (OpenFOAM) package. OpenFOAM is a free, open source
Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) software package. The numerical model has been set up as
two dimensional (2D), transient, incompressible and turbulent flow. A standard high Reynolds
number k-ε turbulence model is included to evaluate the turbulence. The objective of the present
work is to set up the case using pimpleFoam solver which is an Unsteady Reynolds Averaged
Simulations (URANS) model and to evaluate the model for its conformance with available
literature and experiments. The results obtained are compared with experimental and numerical
data.
Introduction
The flow is classified in to laminar and turbulent based on the Reynolds number (i.e
Re=U
.D/ν) as for laminar Re< 2000, for turbulent Re>4000 and 2000<Re>4000 is transition
region. Many experimental and numerical simulations have been carried out for laminar and
turbulent flows. But very high Reynolds no flow conditions are very hard and expensive in an
experimental set up requiring appropriate experimental facilities for minimizing human and
instrument errors during measuring hydrodynamic quantities. Therefore an attractive alternative is
to use Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) to obtain the essential hydrodynamic quantities
needed for engineering design. To date, not many experimental and numerical simulations have
been performed to predict very high Reynolds number flows (Re > 10
) around a smooth circular
cylinder due to the complexity of the flow. E. Achenbach [1] has done experimental investigation at
Reynolds numbers, 6 x 10
< Re < 5 x 10
and obtained data which allow one to define three states
of the flow: the subcritical flow, where the boundary layer Separates laminarly; the critical flow, in
which a separation bubble, followed by a turbulent reattachment, occurs; and the supercritical flow,
where an immediate transition from the laminar to the turbulent boundary layer is observed at a
critical distance from the stagnation point. Celik and Shaffer [2] showed that there are significant
differences between calculated and measured mean flow parameters. Cantalano, Wang, Iaccarino
and Moin [3] found Large Eddy Simulations (LES) are considerably more accurate than the RANS
results but pretty expensive.
Hence the main objective of the present study is to evaluate whether the standard high
Reynolds number k -ε model is applicable for engineering applications of high Reynolds number of
the order of 10
. The flow around a 2D smooth circular cylinder at Re=3.6X10
is investigated
numerically, and these results are compared with available experimental data and the numerical
results reported by Catalano et al. [3] and Singh and Mittal [4].

factors. But this has implications for the time-accuracy of the solution, because events that are
shorter than the time step are missed completely by the solver. A too large time step generally
smears the solution, regardless of the grid resolution. When using pimpleFoam one has to keep in
mind that too large Co numbers risk reducing the accuracy of the solution. Hence time step is
chosen in such a way that Co
is less than 1.

Keywords : High Reynolds Number, Turbulent Flow, URANS, OpenFOAM, pimpleFoam
Abstract: Flow past a smooth circular cylinder at high Reynolds number (Re=3.6 x 10
) which
covers the upper-transition regime has been investigated numerically by using Open source Field
Operation and Manipulation (OpenFOAM) package. OpenFOAM is a free, open source
Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) software package. The numerical model has been set up as
two dimensional (2D), transient, incompressible and turbulent flow. A standard high Reynolds
number k-ε turbulence model is included to evaluate the turbulence. The objective of the present
work is to set up the case using pimpleFoam solver which is an Unsteady Reynolds Averaged
Simulations (URANS) model and to evaluate the model for its conformance with available
literature and experiments. The results obtained are compared with experimental and numerical
data.
Introduction
The flow is classified in to laminar and turbulent based on the Reynolds number (i.e
Re=U
.D/ν) as for laminar Re< 2000, for turbulent Re>4000 and 2000<Re>4000 is transition
region. Many experimental and numerical simulations have been carried out for laminar and
turbulent flows. But very high Reynolds no flow conditions are very hard and expensive in an
experimental set up requiring appropriate experimental facilities for minimizing human and
instrument errors during measuring hydrodynamic quantities. Therefore an attractive alternative is
to use Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) to obtain the essential hydrodynamic quantities
needed for engineering design. To date, not many experimental and numerical simulations have
been performed to predict very high Reynolds number flows (Re > 10
) around a smooth circular
cylinder due to the complexity of the flow. E. Achenbach [1] has done experimental investigation at
Reynolds numbers, 6 x 10
< Re < 5 x 10
and obtained data which allow one to define three states
of the flow: the subcritical flow, where the boundary layer Separates laminarly; the critical flow, in
which a separation bubble, followed by a turbulent reattachment, occurs; and the supercritical flow,
where an immediate transition from the laminar to the turbulent boundary layer is observed at a
critical distance from the stagnation point. Celik and Shaffer [2] showed that there are significant
differences between calculated and measured mean flow parameters. Cantalano, Wang, Iaccarino
and Moin [3] found Large Eddy Simulations (LES) are considerably more accurate than the RANS
results but pretty expensive.
Hence the main objective of the present study is to evaluate whether the standard high
Reynolds number k -ε model is applicable for engineering applications of high Reynolds number of
the order of 10
. The flow around a 2D smooth circular cylinder at Re=3.6X10
is investigated
numerically, and these results are compared with available experimental data and the numerical
results reported by Catalano et al. [3] and Singh and Mittal [4].
Numerical Simulation
Flow simulation is carried out by using OpenFoam. The physics of the flow is considered as
Page 2:
case. pimpleFoam algorithm uses an inner PISO loop to get an initial solution, which is then under-
relaxed and corrected using an outer SIMPLE loop. This method enables unsteady simulations at
Courant number (Co) numbers larger than 1. In theory, very large Co numbers could be maintained
if a large number of SIMPLE correction loops were applied along with large under-relaxation
factors. But this has implications for the time-accuracy of the solution, because events that are
shorter than the time step are missed completely by the solver. A too large time step generally
smears the solution, regardless of the grid resolution. When using pimpleFoam one has to keep in
mind that too large Co numbers risk reducing the accuracy of the solution. Hence time step is
chosen in such a way that Co
is less than 1.

Conclusion
The flow around a 2D smooth circular cylinder has been computed for very high Reynolds
number at the upper-transition flow regime, using the 2D RANS in conjunction with a standard
high Reynolds number k -ε model. Although it has been shown earlier that this model gives less
accurate predictions of flow with strong anisotropic turbulence, the present study shows that for
engineering design purposes it gives satisfactory qualitative agreements with the published
experimental data and numerical results in the supercritical and upper-transition flow regimes, i.e.
Re >10
. The present study should be reliable and useful as an engineering assessment tool for
design work.

TRANSIENT SIMULATION OF FLOW PAST SMOOTH CIRCULAR
CYLINDER AT VERY HIGH REYNOLDS NUMBER USING OpenFOAM
Sangamesh.M.Hosur

Keywords : High Reynolds Number, Turbulent Flow, URANS, OpenFOAM, pimpleFoam
Abstract: Flow past a smooth circular cylinder at high Reynolds number (Re=3.6 x 10
) which
covers the upper-transition regime has been investigated numerically by using Open source Field
Operation and Manipulation (OpenFOAM) package. OpenFOAM is a free, open source
Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) software package. The numerical model has been set up as
two dimensional (2D), transient, incompressible and turbulent flow. A standard high Reynolds
number k-ε turbulence model is included to evaluate the turbulence. The objective of the present
work is to set up the case using pimpleFoam solver which is an Unsteady Reynolds Averaged
Simulations (URANS) model and to evaluate the model for its conformance with available
literature and experiments. The results obtained are compared with experimental and numerical
data.
Introduction
The flow is classified in to laminar and turbulent based on the Reynolds number (i.e
Re=U
.D/ν) as for laminar Re< 2000, for turbulent Re>4000 and 2000<Re>4000 is transition
region. Many experimental and numerical simulations have been carried out for laminar and
turbulent flows. But very high Reynolds no flow conditions are very hard and expensive in an
experimental set up requiring appropriate experimental facilities for minimizing human and
instrument errors during measuring hydrodynamic quantities. Therefore an attractive alternative is
to use Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) to obtain the essential hydrodynamic quantities
needed for engineering design. To date, not many experimental and numerical simulations have
been performed to predict very high Reynolds number flows (Re > 10
) around a smooth circular
cylinder due to the complexity of the flow. E. Achenbach [1] has done experimental investigation at
Reynolds numbers, 6 x 10
< Re < 5 x 10
and obtained data which allow one to define three states
of the flow: the subcritical flow, where the boundary layer Separates laminarly; the critical flow, in
which a separation bubble, followed by a turbulent reattachment, occurs; and the supercritical flow,
where an immediate transition from the laminar to the turbulent boundary layer is observed at a
critical distance from the stagnation point. Celik and Shaffer [2] showed that there are significant
differences between calculated and measured mean flow parameters. Cantalano, Wang, Iaccarino
and Moin [3] found Large Eddy Simulations (LES) are considerably more accurate than the RANS
results but pretty expensive.
Hence the main objective of the present study is to evaluate whether the standard high
Reynolds number k -ε model is applicable for engineering applications of high Reynolds number of
the order of 10
. The flow around a 2D smooth circular cylinder at Re=3.6X10
is investigated
numerically, and these results are compared with available experimental data and the numerical
results reported by Catalano et al. [3] and Singh and Mittal [4].
Numerical Simulation
Flow simulation is carried out by using OpenFoam. The physics of the flow is considered as
Page 2:
case. pimpleFoam algorithm uses an inner PISO loop to get an initial solution, which is then under-
relaxed and corrected using an outer SIMPLE loop. This method enables unsteady simulations at
Courant number (Co) numbers larger than 1. In theory, very large Co numbers could be maintained
if a large number of SIMPLE correction loops were applied along with large under-relaxation
factors. But this has implications for the time-accuracy of the solution, because events that are
shorter than the time step are missed completely by the solver. A too large time step generally
smears the solution, regardless of the grid resolution. When using pimpleFoam one has to keep in
mind that too large Co numbers risk reducing the accuracy of the solution. Hence time step is
chosen in such a way that Co
is less than 1.

Conclusion
The flow around a 2D smooth circular cylinder has been computed for very high Reynolds
number at the upper-transition flow regime, using the 2D RANS in conjunction with a standard
high Reynolds number k -ε model. Although it has been shown earlier that this model gives less
accurate predictions of flow with strong anisotropic turbulence, the present study shows that for
engineering design purposes it gives satisfactory qualitative agreements with the published
experimental data and numerical results in the supercritical and upper-transition flow regimes, i.e.
Re >10
. The present study should be reliable and useful as an engineering assessment tool for
design work.

But according to the JSON, for right, up, down, U is inletOutlet. The inletOutlet BC in OpenFOAM switches between fixedValue and zeroGradient based on the flow direction. Abstract: Flow past a smooth circular cylinder at high Reynolds number (Re=3.6 x 10
) which
covers the upper-transition regime has been investigated numerically by using Open source Field
Operation and Manipulation (OpenFOAM) package. OpenFOAM is a free, open source
Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) software package. The numerical model has been set up as
two dimensional (2D), transient, incompressible and turbulent flow. A standard high Reynolds
number k-ε turbulence model is included to evaluate the turbulence. The objective of the present
work is to set up the case using pimpleFoam solver which is an Unsteady Reynolds Averaged
Simulations (URANS) model and to evaluate the model for its conformance with available
literature and experiments. The results obtained are compared with experimental and numerical
data.
Introduction
The flow is classified in to laminar and turbulent based on the Reynolds number (i.e
Re=U
.D/ν) as for laminar Re< 2000, for turbulent Re>4000 and 2000<Re>4000 is transition
region. Many experimental and numerical simulations have been carried out for laminar and
turbulent flows. But very high Reynolds no flow conditions are very hard and expensive in an
experimental set up requiring appropriate experimental facilities for minimizing human and
instrument errors during measuring hydrodynamic quantities. Therefore an attractive alternative is
to use Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) to obtain the essential hydrodynamic quantities
needed for engineering design. To date, not many experimental and numerical simulations have
been performed to predict very high Reynolds number flows (Re > 10
) around a smooth circular
cylinder due to the complexity of the flow. E. Achenbach [1] has done experimental investigation at
Reynolds numbers, 6 x 10
< Re < 5 x 10
and obtained data which allow one to define three states
of the flow: the subcritical flow, where the boundary layer Separates laminarly; the critical flow, in
which a separation bubble, followed by a turbulent reattachment, occurs; and the supercritical flow,
where an immediate transition from the laminar to the turbulent boundary layer is observed at a
critical distance from the stagnation point. Celik and Shaffer [2] showed that there are significant
differences between calculated and measured mean flow parameters. Cantalano, Wang, Iaccarino
and Moin [3] found Large Eddy Simulations (LES) are considerably more accurate than the RANS
results but pretty expensive.
Hence the main objective of the present study is to evaluate whether the standard high
Reynolds number k -ε model is applicable for engineering applications of high Reynolds number of
the order of 10
. The flow around a 2D smooth circular cylinder at Re=3.6X10
is investigated
numerically, and these results are compared with available experimental data and the numerical
results reported by Catalano et al. [3] and Singh and Mittal [4].
Numerical Simulation
Flow simulation is carried out by using OpenFoam. The physics of the flow is considered as
Page 2:
case. pimpleFoam algorithm uses an inner PISO loop to get an initial solution, which is then under-
relaxed and corrected using an outer SIMPLE loop. This method enables unsteady simulations at
Courant number (Co) numbers larger than 1. In theory, very large Co numbers could be maintained
if a large number of SIMPLE correction loops were applied along with large under-relaxation
factors. But this has implications for the time-accuracy of the solution, because events that are
shorter than the time step are missed completely by the solver. A too large time step generally
smears the solution, regardless of the grid resolution. When using pimpleFoam one has to keep in
mind that too large Co numbers risk reducing the accuracy of the solution. Hence time step is
chosen in such a way that Co
is less than 1.

Conclusion
The flow around a 2D smooth circular cylinder has been computed for very high Reynolds
number at the upper-transition flow regime, using the 2D RANS in conjunction with a standard
high Reynolds number k -ε model. Although it has been shown earlier that this model gives less
accurate predictions of flow with strong anisotropic turbulence, the present study shows that for
engineering design purposes it gives satisfactory qualitative agreements with the published

reasoning_content:
Okay, let me start by understanding what the user needs. They want to simulate a 2D transient incompressible turbulent flow around a smooth circular cylinder at Re=3.6e6 using URANS with the standard high-Re k-epsilon model in OpenFOAM-v2406. The domain size is 40Dx20D, with U_infty=3.6m/s, turbulence intensity 3.22%, and time steps controlled for Co<1. They also want the case files set up using pimpleFoam and kEpsilon, following specific initial and boundary conditions provided in a JSON format.

First, I need to extract the necessary parameters from the research paper excerpts provided. The key parameters include Re=3.6e6, URANS with k-epsilon model, domain size, boundary conditions, and comparison data. The paper mentions using OpenFOAM's pimpleFoam solver, which combines PISO and SIMPLE algorithms for transient simulations. The turbulence model is the standard high-Re k-epsilon, which is crucial for setting up the turbulenceProperties file.

Next, I need to structure the OpenFOAM case files as per the user's request. The files required are 0/p, 0/U, 0/k, 0/epsilon, 0/nut, constant/transportProperties, constant/turbulenceProperties, system/controlDict, system/fvSchemes, and system/fvSolution. Each of these files must adhere to the initial and boundary conditions specified in the JSON.

Starting with the 0 directory files. For 0/p, the initial condition is 0, and the boundary conditions for the cylinder are zeroGradient. The defaultFaces are set to empty because it's a 2D case. The left, right, up, and down boundaries have zeroGradient for pressure. The turbulence fields (k, epsilon, nut) need to be initialized with the values provided. The cylinder wall uses wall functions for k and epsilon, while the inlet (left) uses fixedValue for k and epsilon, and inletOutlet for others. The nut file uses calculated for most boundaries except the cylinder, which uses nutkWallFunction.

The constant directory files: transportProperties sets the kinematic viscosity nu. Since Re=3.6e6, and U=3.6 m/s, D can be calculated if needed, but the user mentioned the grid is already prepared, so nu might be derived from Re=UD/ν. However, the exact value isn't provided, but the initial conditions for nut are given. The turbulenceProperties file specifies the RAS model as kEpsilon and turbulence on, with printCoeffs enabled.

In the system directory, controlDict must use pimpleFoam as the application. The startTime is 0, endTime 30, deltaT 0.005, writeControl timeStep, writeInterval 100, etc. The adjustTimeStep is set to yes with maxCo 1 and maxDeltaT 0.01 to maintain Co<1. The fvSchemes uses Gauss linear for grad, div, laplacian, and interpolation. Time derivatives are Euler, and the flux is vanLeer.
